case_name: University of Delhi and Principal, Miranda House, University College for Women v. Ram Nath and Asgar Masih

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 650 and 651 of 1962 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 650 and 651 of 1962. Appeals by special leave

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from order dated September 22, 1961 of the Labour Court, Delhi, in L C. A No. 479 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the order dated September 22, 1961 of the Labour Court, Delhi, in L C. A No. 479 of 1961.

facts.text: Ram Nath and Asgar Masih filed petitions under section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 against University of Delhi and Principal, Miranda House.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave arise out of two petitions filed against the University of Delhi and Principal, Miranda House, University College for Women, appellants 1 and 2, by two of their employees Ram Nath and Asgar Masih

facts.text: University College for Women run by University of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 2 which is the University College for women is run by appellant No. 1

facts.text: Ram Nath employed as driver by appellant No. 2 in October, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Naths case was that he had been employed as driver by appellant No. 2 in October, 1949

facts.text: Ram Nath served with notice on May 1, 1961 that services no longer required, discharged on payment of one month's salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: and was served with a numberice on May 1, 1961, that since his services were numberlonger required, he would be discharged from his employment on payment of one months salary in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: Asgar Masih employed by appellant No. 1 as driver, transferred to appellant No. 2 on October 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Asgar Masih made substantially similar allegations. He bad been employed in the first instance, by appellant No. 1 as driver but was then transferred to appellant No. 2 on October 1, 1949.

facts.text: Asgar Masih services terminated by notice on May 1, 1961 on payment of one month's salary in advance in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: His services were similarly terminated by numberice on May 1, 1961 on payment of one months salary in advance in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 discontinued running buses for convenience of girl students attending college run by appellant No. 2 due to loss.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that appellant No. 1 found that running the buses for the companyvenience of the girl students attending the companylege run by appellant No. 2 resulted in loss, and so, it was decided to discontinue that amenity.

facts.text: Services of the two drivers retrenched due to discontinuation of bus service.

anchor.surface_text: Inevitablely, the services of the two drivers had to be retrenched

facts.text: Retrenchment is genuine, no element of mala fides or unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: and so, there is numberdispute that the retrenchment is genuine and there is numberelement of mala fides or unfair labour practice involved in it.

facts.text: If employees are workmen and work is industry under s.2(j), section 25F not complied with and retrenchment amount not paid.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that if the employees are workmen within the meaning of the Act, and the work carried on by the appellants is an industry under s. 2 j , section 25F has number been companyplied with and retrenchment amount payable under it has number been paid to the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 resisted petitions on ground not employer under s.2(g), work not industry under s.2(j), applications incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions made by the respondents were resisted by appellant No. 1 on the preliminary ground that appellant No. 1 was number an employer under s. 2 g , that the work carried on by it was number an industry under s. 2 j , and so, the applications made under section 33C 2  were incompetent.

facts.text: Labour Court rejected preliminary objection, considered merits, directed appellants to pay Rs. 10,50/- to each respondent as retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has rejected this preliminary objection and having companysidered the merits, has passed an order in favour of the respondents directing the appellants to pay Rs. 10,50/- to each one of the respondents as retrenchment companypensation.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 1, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 1. The judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-

facts.text: University of Delhi established under Delhi University Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This University has been established and incorporated as a teaching and affiliating University under the Delhi University Act, 1922  No. 8 of 1922 .

facts.text: Teachers employed by educational institutions are not workmen under s.2(s).

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that teachers employed by educational institutions, whether the said institutions are imparting primary., secondary, companylegiate or postgraduate education, are number workmen under s. 2 s

facts.text: Work of education carried on primarily with assistance of teachers.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the fact that the work of education is primarily and exclusively carried on with the assistance of the labour and companyoperation of teachers

facts.text: University of Delhi receives grants from Central Government, University Grants Commission, charitable donors, tuition fees.

anchor.surface_text: It receives grants from the Central Government, from the University Grants Commission and from charitable donors and charitable institutions. It also receives some income from tuition fees.

facts.text: Supreme Court held University of Delhi not carrying on industry under s.2(j), applications under s.33C(2) incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the University of Delhi and the Miranda College for Women run by it cannot be regarded as carrying on an industry under s. 2 j , and so, the applications made by the respondents against them under s. 33 C 2  of the Act must be held to be incompetent.

facts.text: Appeals allowed, orders of Industrial Tribunal set aside, petitions dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are allowed,, the orders passed by the Industrial Tribunal arc set aside and the petitions filed by the respondents under s. 33 C  2  of the Act are dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the work carried on by appellant No. 1 is an industry under s.2(j)

anchor.surface_text: It is the validity of this award that is challenged before us by the appellants, and the only ground on which the challenge is made is that the work carried on by appellant No. 1 is, number an industry under s.2 j . Though the question thus raised by these two appeals lies within a narrow compass,

issues.text: Whether appellant No. 1 was an employer under s.2(g)

anchor.surface_text: The petitions made by the respondents were resisted by appellant No. 1 on the preliminary ground that appellant No. 1 was number an employer under s. 2 g , that the work carried on by it was number an industry under s. 2 j , and so, the applications made under section 33C 2  were incompetent.

issues.text: Whether the applications made under section 33C(2) were competent

anchor.surface_text: The petitions made by the respondents were resisted by appellant No. 1 on the preliminary ground that appellant No. 1 was number an employer under s. 2 g , that the work carried on by it was number an industry under s. 2 j , and so, the applications made under section 33C 2  were incompetent. The Tribunal has rejected this preliminary objection

issues.text: Whether reading ss. 2(g), 2(j) and 2(s) together, the work of education carried on by educational institutions like the University of Delhi is an industry within the meaning of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Reading ss. 2 g ,  j  and  s  together, we are inclined to hold that the work of education carried on by educational institutions like the University of Delhi is number an industry within the meaning of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the definition of industry under s.2(j) should be given its widest denotation by adopting a mechanical and literal rule of construction

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the Tribunal was in error in giving the definition of the word industry under s. 2  j  its widest denotation by adopting a mechanical and literal rule of companystruction and it is urged that.the policy of the Act clearly is to leave education and educational.

arguments.claim: Purpose of education not assimilable to trade/business; incongruous as industry

anchor.surface_text: Having reached this conclusion, it may be legitimate to observe that it is number surprising that the Act should have excluded education from its scope, because the distinctive purpose and object of education would make it very difficult to assimilate it to the position of any trade, business or calling or service within the meaning of s. 2 j

arguments.claim: University contributes no capital; work by teachers' cooperation, not trade/business

It receives grants from the Central Government, from the University Grants Commission and from charitable donors and charitable institutions. It also receives some income from tuition fees.

arguments.claim: Subordinate staff minor/insignificant; predominant activity of education excludes industry character

anchor.surface_text: It is true that like all educational institutions the University of Delhi employs subordinate staff and this subordinate staff does the work assigned to it but in the main scheme of imparting education, this subordinate staff plays such a minor, subsidiary and insignificant part that it would be unreasonable to allow this work to lend its industrial colour to the principal activity of the University which is imparting education.

arguments.claim: Hospital Mazdoor Sabha left educational institutions open; does not support inclusion

anchor.surface_text: The first decision to which reference must be made is the case of the Hospital Mazdoor Sabha  1 . holdings.text: Reading ss. 2 g , j and s together, we are inclined to hold that the work of education carried on by educational institutions like the University of Delhi is not an industry within the meaning of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Teachers excluded from s.2(s) definition of workman; education primarily carried out by teachers; treating education as industry only for minor subordinate staff contrary to legislative policy.

holdings.text: The University of Delhi and the Miranda College for Women run by it cannot be regarded as carrying on an industry under s. 2 j

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the University of Delhi and the Miranda College for Women run by it cannot be regarded as carrying on an industry under s. 2 j , and so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Predominant activity is imparting education by teachers excluded from Act; subordinate staff's minor role does not impart industrial character; no capital contribution or profit motive akin to trade.

holdings.text: the applications made by the respondents against them under s. 33 C 2 of the Act must be held to be incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the University of Delhi and the Miranda College for Women run by it cannot be regarded as carrying on an industry under s. 2 j , and so, the applications made by the respondents against them under s. 33 C 2  of the Act must be held to be incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No industry under s.2(j) means no employer under s.2(g); thus no jurisdiction under s.33C(2).

holdings.text: it would be unreasonable to hold that educational institutions are employers within the meaning of s. 2 g , or that the work of teaching carried on by them is an industry under s. 2 j

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from not being industry; education as mission not trade; teachers not workmen.

holdings.text: the predominant activity of the University of Delhi is outside the Act, because teaching and teachers connected with it do not come within its purview, and so, the minor and incidental activity carried on by the subordinate staff which may fall within the purview of the Act cannot alter the predominant character of the institution.

anchor.surface_text: The predominant activity of the University of Delhi is outside the Act, because teaching and teachers connected with it do number companye within its purview, and so, the minor and incidental activity carried on by the subordinate staff which may fall within the purview of the Act cannot alter the predominant character of the institution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying predominant activity test from Nagpur Corporation case; education predominant, subordinate work minor.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. The Hospital Mazdoor Sabha 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay v. The Hospital Mazdoor Sabha  1 . In that case, this Court observed that as a working principle, it may be stated that an activity systematically or habitually undertaken for the production or distribution of goods or for the rendering of material services to the companymunity at large or a part of such companymunity with the help of employees is an undertaking. Such an activity generally involves the companyoperation of the employer- and the employees and its object is the satisfaction of material human needs.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of industry under s. 2(j) in words of widest amplitude; working principle that activity for rendering material services to community with employees' help is industry

precedents.citation: Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Pilibhit v. Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Workers Union, Pilibhit

anchor.surface_text: Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Pilibhit v. Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Workers Union, Pilibhit  , . Having held that on the broad facts proved in -that case, there was numberdoubt that the activity of the appellant was an undertaking under s. 2 j , the Court proceeded to add that it was number called upon to decide whether running an educational institution would be an industry under the Act.

precedents.case_name: Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Pilibhit v. Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Workers Union Pilibhit
precedents.cited_proposition: activity was an undertaking under s. 2(j) but left open whether running educational institution is industry

precedents.case_name: Ahmedabad Textile Industry's Research Association v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: research association carrying on industry; activities distinct from purely educational institution

precedents.citation: The Federated State School Teachers Association of Australia v. The State of Victoria 4

precedents.case_name: Federated State School Teachers Association of Australia v. State of Victoria
precedents.cited_proposition: whether state educational activities constitute industry; minority view that teachers' dispute is industrial dispute
precedents.cited_holding: majority: state education not industry; minority (Isaacs J): is industry

precedents.citation: The Corporation of the City of Nagpur V. Its Employees, 1

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of the City of Nagpur V. Its Employees,  1  the question which arose for the decision of this Court was whether and to what extent the municipal activities of the Corporation of Nagpur City fell within the term industry as defined by s. 2 14  of the C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of the City of Nagpur v. Its Employees
precedents.cited_proposition: municipal activities including education department constitute industry; predominant nature of activity determines
precedents.cited_holding: most municipal departments including education are industry
